header.title: Class 21 - Introduction to Tarot and Major Arcana
authors: Esoteric School of Shamanism and Magic, 2003

central_thesis: This document introduces modern Tarot as a comprehensive operative system for divination, spell work, and Qabalistic application with the Tree of Life, developed by the Order of the Golden Dawn. It emphasizes the spiritual and archetypal utility of the cards, detailing their symbolic meanings for practical magical and self-transformational purposes, rather than limiting them to mundane interpretations.

structure_content.summary: This section traces the origins of modern Tarot to the Order of the Golden Dawn, highlighting their design of the Waite-Rider, Morgan-Greer, and Thoth decks. These decks are presented as uniquely suited for divination, spell work, and working with the Tree of Life. It discusses the esoteric etymology of 'Tarot' from 'Rota' (wheel) and acknowledges the ancient, broad historical roots of Tarot symbology.

Signifiers are introduced as cards that represent specific individuals or situations, crucial for focusing Tarot readings on particular questions or issues. The selection of signifiers for people is based on chronological age, sun sign, and observed behavior, with specific elemental and astrological correspondences provided for precise identification.

This part differentiates the two main categories of Tarot cards: Major Arcana, which embody universal principles, concepts, and ideals, and Minor Arcana, which illustrate how these principles manifest in the everyday, mundane world. Minor Arcana are organized into four elemental suits (Wands, Swords, Cups, and Plates/Discs), emphasizing that traditional archaic meanings of Major Arcana often differ significantly from modern interpretations.

Detailed interpretations are provided for each Major Arcana card (0-21). For each card, both upright and reversed meanings are explored, with a strong emphasis on their magical, spiritual, and psychological applications, often deviating from common mundane interpretations. Observations contextualize their use within an operative magical framework.

This section provides general elemental associations for each of the four Minor Arcana suits (Wands: Intellect, Swords: Will, Cups: Emotions, Discs: Materiality). Subsequently, specific upright and reversed meanings are given for all numbered cards (Ace through 10) and court cards (Page, Knight, Queen, King) within each suit, detailing their practical manifestation in various life aspects.

structure_content.chapter_title: 6. Meaning of Numbers in the Tarot
structure_content.summary: This part defines the esoteric significance of numbers (Two: Choices, Three: Paths/Foundation, Four: New Force, Five: Resistance, Six: Reward, Seven: Achievement, Eight: Obstacles, Nine: Completion, Ten: Fulfilled Principle) and court ranks (Page: New/Novice, Knight: Aggressive Idealist, Queen: Nourishing/Benevolent, King: Mature Authority). These meanings apply across all four suits, indicating stages of development and manifestation.

A comprehensive list of Major and Minor Arcana cards is provided, specifying their use as signifiers for various situations, entities, and abstract concepts, such as global environments, legal matters, contracts, health aspects, and specific magical operations. This expands the use of signifiers beyond individuals to contextualize readings effectively.

A brief mention of a specific magical instruction for an 'Exit Ritual' is included, directing practitioners to use 'In Willingness' for Day Greetings and Day Endings across six directions, indicating a practical, operative component of the curriculum.

key_concepts.definition: Tarot decks (Waite-Rider, Morgan-Greer, Thoth) developed by the Order of the Golden Dawn, explicitly designed for divination, spell work, and working with the Tree of Life, representing a major advance in magical practice.

A Tarot card chosen to represent a specific person or situation within a reading, used to connect the reading to a particular question or individual. Selection criteria include chronological age, sun sign, and behavioral characteristics.

The 22 trumps of the Tarot deck, representing universal principles, archetypal concepts, or ideals. These cards are not tied to specific suits and address higher spiritual or existential meanings, often differing from modern mundane interpretations.

The 56 suit cards of the Tarot deck, representing the manifestation of major principles in the everyday or mundane world. They are divided into four suits (Wands, Swords, Cups, Plates/Discs), corresponding to the four elemental tools.

A central Qabalistic diagram used as a framework for understanding the universe and the self. In this context, Tarot is used to 'work the Tree of Life' for profound magical undertakings ('great work') and spiritual development.

The original spelling of 'Tarot,' meaning 'wheel.' It signifies the deck's comprehensive representation of all phenomenal experience and the 'wheel of life,' underscoring the Tarot as a simulacrum of the Universe.

Represents power and control, individual mastery of the four elements through intellect and will, high-level magic, deliberate creation, and intentional miracle working. Upright signifies balanced magical use; reversed indicates misuse or refusal of magic.

Represents female magic, intuition, religious social values, psychic abilities, and 'soft magic' derived from a religious or emotional base. Upright suggests proficiency in magic, especially for females; reversed indicates negative religious values or spell-work, and persecution.

Represents natural government, planetary ecology, the laws of the Universe (Grandmother/Earth-system), and the ideal archetype of womanhood (Mother Nature). Upright indicates alignment with natural law; reversed signifies being at odds with natural order, pollution, or abuse of resources.

Represents man's government, mundane laws, social structure, male-oriented values, and authority figures. Upright signifies adherence to strict standards for behavior and power over others; reversed indicates problems with law, authority, or masculine image.

Represents spiritual fairness, mediation, and acting as a bridge between lower and higher levels or communities. Upright signifies ensuring communication, negotiation, and discerning true motivations; reversed indicates spiritual unfairness, lack of negotiation, or fixed stubbornness.

Primarily signifies higher spiritual relationships (karmic, destined, soul mates), internal balance, and the integration of masculine/feminine or dark/light aspects of the self (Yin/Yang). It is the 'higher octave' of the Two of Cups.

Represents full control of personal power, mastery of situations, taking responsibility for one's fate, and maintaining focused attention in both physical and spiritual worlds. Upright indicates personal control; reversed suggests being out of control and self-inflicted loss.

Represents strength with balance, will under intellect, control of one's will, temper, and energy, perseverance from a higher place, and adherence to appropriateness. Crowley's 'Lust' emphasizes potential negative emotional involvement.

Represents wisdom seeking, pursuit of enlightenment, and intentional withdrawal for balanced perspective and contemplation of learned experience. Upright signifies intelligent seeking of wisdom; reversed indicates spiritual blindness, inability to trust oneself, or closing down to wisdom.

Represents the environment of the Universe, its spiritual world, and its relationship to universal laws and higher deities. It is not about personal mundane fortune but rather karmic forces and galactic influences. It serves as a bridge card to relate mundane to higher levels.

Represents what is just according to universal law and the 'Rules of the Road,' focusing on operational laws of the Universe and appropriate conduct, rather than personal fairness. Upright indicates alignment with higher laws; reversed signifies major spiritual injustice.

Represents a thirst for knowledge, spiritual introspection, questioning major issues of knowledge as a spiritual being, and verifying learned information through direct experience. Upright indicates commitment to truth-seeking; reversed suggests an incorrect way of gaining knowledge or ignoring lessons.

Signifies major, usually sudden, unexpected endings that lead to new beginnings in the spiritual realm, representing transformation, rebirth, and the completion of cycles. Upright implies awareness and control over these changes; reversed suggests being caught by surprise or disruptive changes.

Represents maintaining internal balance through intellect, will, and feeling, constant self-observation, vigilance, and making spiritual choices. It signifies small adjustments in the present yielding larger changes in the future, balancing spiritual and material with tension.

Relates to how a spiritual being handles agreed-upon contracts in the material world, emphasizing commitment and impeccability in balancing spiritual and material aspects. It has little to do with the Christian Satan, representing instead materialism, 'mendacious' trickery, or hidden contracts.

Represents sudden, abrupt chaos or complete material disorganization caused by spiritual forces outside of one's control. Upright indicates natural chaos that can lead to improvement; reversed suggests destructive change, perhaps karmic or due to breaking 'Rules of the Road'.

Represents automatic spiritual balance, achieved through past efforts, where inner balance radiates externally. This state allows for true flow of manifestation, relaxation, and the ability to project what one has to guide others ('As above, so below' projection).

Represents the beginning of the spiritual journey, crawling out of emotional turmoil, transforming lower emotions into compassion and understanding, and opening to intuition. Upright suggests spiritual progress; reversed indicates falling back into emotionality, passion, or controlling others with feelings.

Represents spiritual health, growth potential, nourishment, and how one affects their environment. It signifies fulfilling one's birth vision, demonstrating higher principles, and radiating positive influence. Also used for spell send-backs and as an indicator of spiritual expression.

Represents the spirit accessing and judging its entire life path and past experiences from its own perspective, integrating past experience with present judgment. Upright signifies good spiritual judgment and high manifestation ability; reversed indicates terrible judgment or not learning from past experience.

Represents the world's environment, global and galactic changes, and how the material physical world affects an individual. It pertains to higher order universal laws, astrological influences, and the interrelation with extraterrestrial forces, indicating conditions affecting a situation rather than personal issues.

Represents spiritual mastery, a balanced perspective, inherent optimism, readiness for spiritual endeavors, openness to learning, and nimbleness. It is the first and last card on the Tree of Life, signifying someone who knows the pitfalls but operates with full trust and control. Reversed suggests foolishness, spiritual bankruptcy, or arrogance.

practical_system.description: The system utilizes specific Tarot decks (Waite-Rider, Morgan-Greer, Thoth) as primary tools for three core functions: divination, spell work, and working with the Tree of Life. It requires a deep understanding of card meanings beyond mundane interpretations, focusing on spiritual principles, elemental correspondences, and the interplay between Major and Minor Arcana. Key to practice are the precise selection and use of signifiers to focus readings and the application of card meanings to personal spiritual development, magical operations, and understanding universal laws.
tools: Quartz crystal rod (associated with the Magician for infinite energy and elemental control)
rituals: Exit Ritual (using 'In Willingness' for Day Greetings and Day Endings, 6 directions)
Spell work (for various magical intentions, with specific Major Arcana cards like Magician, High Priestess, and Sun being indicative of different types of magic or spell effects)
Working the Tree of Life (for 'doing a great work,' implying advanced Qabalistic operations)
Negotiating as the Hierophant (e.g., for weather manipulation, acting as a spiritual mediator)

relevant_quotes.text: Arthur Edward Waite created the Waite-Rider deck (Rider was the name of the publisher) and Pamela Smith, also of the Golden Dawn, did the artwork for the cards.

Aleister Crowley, who created the Thoth deck, disagreed with all of them saying, “You're all nuts. Everyone out in the world is all involved in all this mundane level stuff, and none of them are up to the point of starting the Tree of Life. They need to deal with their baser things. So, a pox on both your houses! We ought to work with the reverse Tree to throw them into that. If you haven't the sense to recognize that then it be on their own heads. If they get caught in the pit then it be on their own heads.”

However, the modern Tarot is brand new, revised by the Order of the Golden Dawn to work more intimately with the Tree of Life and for spell work. It's a development of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, and is, in our estimation, the major advance in magical practice within the last 2,000 years.

The word Tarot is a disguised word. It was originally spelled “Rota,” which means wheel, because the deck represents all phenomenal experience, the wheel of life. We use the Tarot as a living form that is tied into the existing Universe. In essence, the Tarot is a simulacrum of the Universe.
Most people who use the Tarot today do not use signifiers. We choose signifiers for people based on chronological age and sun sign.

Major Arcana cards are all the other cards in the deck and are related to but not tied to a particular suit. They represent principles, concepts or ideals while minor arcana cards represent the many ways that those principles manifest in the everyday or mundane world.
The Devil has very little, if anything, to do with the Christian Satan.
Death has very little, if anything, to do with physical death.
The Tarot, as far as putting a lot of things together, is the major advance in magical practice in the last 2000 years because it gives you the tools to handle anything at any level.
The first and last card on the Tree of Life. Just above the aces at the bottom of the tree. The last step on the tree is the Fool.

critical_analysis.relevance: This document is highly relevant for practitioners of Hermetic Qabalah, Golden Dawn-style ceremonial magic, and operative Tarot. It positions Tarot not merely as a divinatory tool but as a sophisticated magical system for self-transformation, spell work, and aligning with universal laws. Its emphasis on specific decks originating from the Golden Dawn tradition makes it particularly pertinent to those studying or actively practicing Hermetic magic, providing detailed operative interpretations that extend beyond common or simplified Tarot guides.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience consists of students and practitioners of the Esoteric School of Shamanism and Magic, as implied by the copyright and class title. It is also suitable for serious students of Western Esotericism, Occultism, and Magic who seek a deep, operative, and Qabalistically-informed understanding of Tarot, aiming to integrate its use into practical spellcraft and personal spiritual development beyond basic divination.
